sentences: Deborah Dugan is an American executive who was the first female president and CEO of the Recording Academy, which presents the Grammy Awards, in 2019 and 2020.

She served as the president of Disney Publishing Worldwide from 2002 to 2006, having been at the company a total eight years, and CEO of Entertainment Rights North America from 2007 to 2009, and CEO of (RED) from 2011 to 2019.

She served as the president of Disney Publishing Worldwide from 2002 to 2006, having been at the company a total eight years, and CEO of Entertainment Rights North America from 2007 to 2009, and CEO of (RED) from 2011 to 2019.

She served as the president of Disney Publishing Worldwide from 2002 to 2006, having been at the company a total eight years, and CEO of Entertainment Rights North America from 2007 to 2009, and CEO of (RED) from 2011 to 2019.
Currently, Dugan is doing strategy work for Handshake, a social impact agency, working with clients such as Reform Alliance and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
She has contributed to the Huffington Post and Forbes.com and appeared on Mad Money with Jim Cramer, PBS News Hour, and NPR's All Things Considered, among other outlets.
Dugan has been the co-chair of the storytelling nonprofit the Moth since 2008.

She then worked for Disney Publishing Worldwide for eight years, becoming its president in 2002, where she oversaw 275 magazines, including Discover and Disney Magazine, and published more than 4,000 new books, generating $1.8 billion in global retail sales.

sentences: Dugan then worked for British media company Entertainment Rights as president and CEO of the North America division, restructuring it and growing its biggest content work, one year, 27 percent.
section: == Career ==

sentences: She was senior advisor to the Tribeca Enterprises Board from 2009 to 2011,  where she evaluated and executed revenue streams for Robert DeNiro and Jane Rosenthal's company and rebranded its school.
section: == Career ==

sentences: In 2011, Dugan started work as CEO of (RED), co-founded by Bono and Bobby Shriver after interviewing for a job that wasn't the right fit.

sentences: The nonprofit aims to enlist the help of private companies and citizens in the global fight to eradicate AIDS in Sub-Saharan Africa (it now tasks itself to also combat the effects of COVID-19).

sentences: In response to the outrage over the low female representation at the 2018 Grammys and then-CEO/President Neil Portnow's comment that women musicians needed to "step up" in order to achieve parity, an 18-person task force led by Time's Up co-founder Tina Tchen was created to study the Recording Academy's problems and make recommendations.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: After a search, on May 8, 2019, its board of trustees confirmed that Dugan would be its next president and CEO.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: She began her tenure on August 1, 2019, succeeding Portnow.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: Dugan was the first woman president of the $60M nonprofit, and her contract was for three years.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: On January 16, 2020, Dugan was relieved of her duties and placed on administrative leave, accused of bullying her assistant, whom she inherited from Portnow, resulting in the assistant taking a leave of absence.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: On March 2, 2020, the Recording Academy announced that it had officially fired her.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: The organization also tightened their conflict of interest rules that June.
section: == Career == | === Recording Academy presidency and settlement ===

sentences: In April 2021, the Recording Academy eliminated its secret voting committees that existed for 28 years.
